JournalInfo.JournalTitle: International Journal of Multimedia Information Retrieval

ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Optimizing visual dictionaries for effective image retrieval

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Computer Science and Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
Characterizing images by high-level concepts from a learned visual dictionary is extensively used in image classification and retrieval. This paper deals with inferring discriminative visual dictionaries for effective image retrieval and examines a non-negative visual dictionary learning scheme towards this direction. More specifically, a non-negative matrix factorization framework with
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-sparseness constraint on the coefficient matrix for optimizing the dictionary is proposed. It is a two-step iterative process composed of sparse encoding and dictionary enhancement stages. An initial estimate of the visual dictionary is updated in each iteration with the proposed
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-constraint gradient projection algorithm. A desirable attribute of this formulation is an adaptive sequential dictionary initialization procedure. This leads to a sharp drop down of the approximation error and a faster convergence. Finally, the proposed dictionary optimization scheme is used to derive a compact image representation for the retrieval task. A new image signature is obtained by projecting local descriptors on to the basis elements of the optimized visual dictionary and then aggregating the resulting sparse encodings in to a single feature vector. Experimental results on various benchmark datasets show that the proposed system can infer enhanced visual dictionaries and the derived image feature vector can achieve better retrieval results as compared to state-of-the-art techniques.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Visual dictionaries (codebooks) are either created from a predefined set of functions or can be learned from an appropriate collection of training samples. However, in practice the learned dictionaries are shown to be superior in various applications of signal and image processing domains [1, 2]. The learning algorithms often result much fine-tuned dictionaries and provide significantly better performance. But, most of these generated dictionaries are unstructured in nature. Moreover, the size of the dictionaries learned in this fashion as well as the dimension of data that can be efficiently handled by these learning approaches are often limited by certain complexity constraints.

In recent years, non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) [3], which attempts to derive hidden structures from redundant data has been successfully applied to problems in data analysis [4], image processing [5], language modelling [6], text analysis [7], etc. NMF can decompose a given non-negative matrix of observations into a product of two non-negative factor matrices, in which one of them is termed as the basis matrix and the other is known as the coefficient matrix corresponding to the basis elements. Since the non-negativity constraints allow only additive combinations, NMF learns part-based representation of the whole data. That is, at the end of the training process the basis matrix captures additive parts of the input data matrix. Intuitively, the factorization by NMF can be viewed as a structured dictionary learning process provided strict sparseness constraints are enforced on the coefficient matrix.

To obtain a sparser representation, various NMF frameworks with imposed sparsity constraints on the columns of coefficient matrix have been proposed. In all such formulations, the basic idea is to represent an input sample as a linear combination of a few basis vectors from the learned dictionary. The sparseness of coefficient vectors is usually defined as a function of its
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-norm,
$$\ell _1$$
ℓ 1
-norm or
$$\ell _2$$
ℓ 2
-norm [8]. Among the various sparsity enforcing functions, the more intuitive one which directly allows us to specify the number of maximum possible non-zero entries in each of coefficient vectors is the
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-norm. Such a clear intuition of sparsity cannot be directly provided by the rest of the measures. However, there exist only few works in the literature concerned with
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-constrained NMF, namely NN-KSVD [9], NMF
$$\ell ^0$$
ℓ 0
-H [10] and K-WEB [11]. Starting with a random initialization of the dictionary elements, all these
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-constrained NMF algorithms involves a two-step iterative procedure that enhances the basis and coefficient matrices alternatively. During dictionary updating stage, the columns of the basis matrix are refined individually by selecting one basis element at a time. This makes them computationally expensive and leads to slower convergence for dictionaries of larger sizes. Moreover, random initialization of basis matrix by positive numbers that are not correlated with the given observations always results in approximations of inferior quality.

This work proposes a new algorithm based on
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-constrained NMF formulation to dictionary learning problem for the sparse encoding of a set of local image features in the context of image retrieval. The presented dictionary optimization framework tries to overcome both of the above-mentioned limitations of existing works. In this regard, an adaptive sequential dictionary initialization scheme is proposed to get an initial estimate of the basis matrix from the training samples itself. A proper non-random initialization can lead to faster error reduction and minimal approximation error at convergence. Afterwards, sparseness preserving
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-constrained gradient projection scheme is proposed to enhance the dictionary. This helps to modify the basis vectors as a whole in contrast to the individual column-wise update in existing frameworks. Numerical experiments show that the proposed scheme converges much faster than other algorithms for the same purpose and at the same time the overall performance is improved remarkably. In addition, the learned dictionaries achieve better basis recovery rate as compared to the conventional methods. Hence, the main contributions of this paper are:
A codebook optimization procedure with an adaptive sequential dictionary initialization scheme and an
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-constrained gradient projection algorithm for enhancing the visual dictionary.
A compact and discriminative image feature well suited for the retrieval task is introduced. The new representation is obtained by sparsely encoding local image features based on the learned dictionary and then aggregating the sparse codes with max pooling operation.
The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section 2 summarizes various visual dictionary learning schemes available in the literature. Section 3 reviews NMF and sparse coding-based approaches for visual dictionary learning and provides an insight into
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-constrained NMF formulation. Section 4 explains the proposed codebook optimization scheme in detail. The aggregation of local image descriptors towards the creation of a compact image signature based on the proposed dictionary learning scheme is presented in Sect. 5. A detailed description of various image data sets used to evaluate the proposed retrieval framework is provided in Sect. 6. Numerical experiments conducted to analyse the discriminative power of the learned visual dictionaries are outlined in Sect. 7. Section 8 evaluates the effectiveness of the proposed image retrieval framework and sum up the obtained results. Section 9 concludes the proposed work by listing the outcome of the research and the future enhancements.

Section1.Heading: Related work
Section1.Para: Visual dictionaries, which seek to learn explicit summarization of large-scale image databases in terms of visual patterns, have been widely explored over the past few years due to its competent performance in image retrieval. Based on the learned dictionary, an image can be encoded by a histogram of visual patterns or basis elements. This enables the estimation of similarity between images at a much higher level of abstraction. Hence, designing a comprehensive model for inferring discriminative visual dictionary is the key towards an efficient image retrieval framework.

Depending on the choice of basis elements, visual dictionaries fall into two major categories: analytical dictionaries and image-dependent dictionaries. Well-known mathematical models which encapsulate the global structure of the given images are employed to gather the prototype elements of analytical dictionaries. To this end, Discrete Cosine Transform [12], Wavelets [13], Curvlets [14] and Bandlets [15]-based representations are successfully adopted in various applications. Irrespective of the underlying image databases all these models support rapid realization but are universal in nature. However, dictionaries estimated from appropriate training samples often perform better as they are more adapted to the statistics of the observed data. Such types of dictionaries are usually derived by optimizing certain cost functions and the associated constraints that reflect the preferred characteristics of the representation. Prominent among such data-driven methods are vector quantization (VQ), principal component analysis (PCA), independent component analysis (ICA), non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) and sparse coding (SC).

In general, the aforementioned image-dependent dictionary learning techniques can be viewed as specific instances of matrix factorization [16] problem. Matrix factorization seeks to find an approximation of a set of data points in the form of a matrix product with significant properties which enable us to capture the intrinsic patterns in the data. Given a set of
$$N$$
N
observations described by D-dimensional column vectors
$$v_i$$
v i
stored in matrix
$$ V \in R^{D \times N}$$
V ∈
R
D × N
, matrix factorization yields an unsupervised linear approximation of
$$V$$
V
as
$$V\approx WH$$
V ≈ W H
. Each column of
$$W$$
W
signifies the learned basis elements and each column of
$$H$$
H
denotes the mixing coefficients or weights of various basis elements in approximating distinct input data.

In vector quantization [17], each data point is approximated by exactly one prototype element. Each column of
$$H$$
H
is constrained to be unary with exactly one element corresponding to unity and all the others set to zeros. K-means clustering algorithm is employed to find the basis vectors. This type of representation is often restrictive and provides a coarse approximation resulting in higher reconstruction error. On the other hand, principal component analysis [18] extract an orthonormal basis with columns of
$$H$$
H
not unary, which approximate each data point as a linear combination of possibly all basis vectors. Although PCA encapsulate the statistical correlation among the training samples, it ignores all higher order data relationships. Hence, independent component analysis [19] that generalizes PCA by discovering statistically independent components from the training data set is introduced. Most of these techniques still give rise to a holistic representation of the input data points with limited interpretation of the decomposition. In addition to lack of explicit visual interpretation, they are vulnerable to changes in input distribution and background noise.

By enforcing additional constraints such as sparseness and non-negativity on decomposition, the level of interpretability of the matrix factorization can be further improved. In this respect, non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) constitutes an analysis of multivariate data under the assumption of non-negative factors [20]. The non-negativity condition enforced on
$$W$$
W
and
$$H$$
H
entitle only additive integration of the discrete basis vectors. Consequently NMF is expected to learn part-based representation [21] of input observations. While applying NMF to face images in [22], the authors demonstrated that the columns of
$$W$$
W
correspond to various parts of the face and the columns of
$$H$$
H
tell us which parts are to be combined in what proportions to get an approximation of individual face data in
$$V$$
V
. As each basis element of the learned dictionary can be interpreted as a high-level concept, a dense visual dictionary deduced by NMF frequently results in the combination of all these concepts to describe each image in the data set. Sparse coding (SC) [23, 24] is a currently accepted matrix factorization approach which helps to resolve this issue. It can infer compact representation of input data by imposing sparsity in the linear combination. This ensures an overcomplete basis set by which each data vector is modelled by a small number of representative basis elements.

Based on the above discussions, it can be concluded that an effective dictionary learning algorithm should incorporate the following characteristics. The intrinsic structure of the training data set should be well encoded by the learned visual dictionary and the description under the learned representation needs to be sparse as well. In view of these two aspects, certain attempts have been made over the past few years with sparseness constraint directly imposed on the coefficient matrix of the basic NMF formulation. Early efforts in this direction restrict the sparsity of coefficient matrix using
$$\ell _1$$
ℓ 1
-norm [25]. But in fact,
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
(pseudo)-norm is the most elementary sparseness metric capable of explicitly specifying the number of maximum feasible non-zero entries in each coefficient vectors. There exist only a few works concerned with NMF having
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-sparseness constraints on the coefficient matrix. Non-negative KSVD (NN-KSVD) introduced by Aharon et al. [9] tries to learn an overcomplete non-negative dictionary for the sparse representation of a set of training signals. It is basically a two-step iterative process repeated until desired number of iterations are reached. In the first step, coefficient matrix
$$H$$
H
is learnt based on the current estimate of the dictionary
$$W$$
W
. Second step performs column-wise update of dictionary
$$W$$
W
. For this, an error matrix is formed for each of the basis element in the dictionary as the residual on the original data matrix
$$V$$
V
while excluding the current basis from the dictionary. Then, the best rank-1 approximation for the error is found through singular value decomposition and the factorization performed is used to update the current basis vector under consideration and its related column vector in the coefficient matrix. NMF
$$\ell ^0$$
ℓ 0
-H developed by Pehraz and Pernkopf [10] employs a sparseness maintaining active set algorithm relying on alternating least squares scheme for
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-sparse NMF. More recently, K-WEB, an extension of NN-KSVD follows a similar approach and replaces the dictionary updating process with a k-weighted Barycenters approach [11].

Section2.Heading: Sparse coding (SC)
Section2.Para:
Several matrix factorization techniques apply certain compactness measures on the dictionary to achieve reduced dimensionality of the transformed representation. Sparse coding realizes this idea by formulating the basis matrix to be overcomplete and insisting sparsity on the columns of coefficient matrix
$$H$$
H
. In this way local image descriptors are approximated using a linear combination of at most
$$L$$
L
basis elements. Here also the Frobenius norm can be employed to quantify the discrepancy between the data matrix
$$V$$
V
and the accomplished model. To incorporate lesser reconstruction error as well as sparsity, SC attempts to solve the following optimization problem. 9
$$\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned}&\underset{W,H}{\text {minimize}}&C(W,H)= \Vert V-WH\Vert _F^2 \\&\text {subject to}&\chi (h_i), \; \forall h_i \in H \end{aligned} \end{aligned}$$

The former compute the number of non-zero entries in a given vector and the latter measures the sum of all entries in the vector. Many algorithms exist in the literature to achieve approximate solutions for sparse coding problem. For a fixed dictionary

Instead of employing pre-determined dictionaries for sparse coding, its basis vectors can also be derived directly from a set of training samples. From a random initialization of the unknowns, this is realized by the gradual enhancement of both the dictionary and the sparse coefficient matrix. K-SVD [34] is a well-known example towards this end.

Section1.Heading: Proposed model for visual dictionary optimization
Section1.Para:
In the context of image retrieval, a visual dictionary helps to map features extracted from images to a set of representative patterns already learned from a training set. Hence, the quality of the learned codebook has a remarkable influence on the image encoding process and in the subsequent retrieval operation. The following subsections briefly summarizes how the proposed
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-constrained NMF formulation can be utilized to generate enhanced visual dictionaries as compared to state-of-the-art techniques. The major steps involved in the proposed unsupervised dictionary learning algorithm are outlined here.

Section2.Heading: Extraction of visual features
Section2.Para:
The first step in building a visual dictionary is the extraction of appropriate visual features from images. A suitable collection of training images has to be analysed for this purpose. There are numerous methods available in the literature to obtain salient features from images. They can be grouped into dense and sparse sampling-based approaches. In dense sampling [36], visual features are extracted from either overlapping or non-overlapping segments evenly spaced on a predefined grid. On the other hand, sparse sampling [37] analyses images with the help of interest point detectors probably at multiple scales. Visual features are then derived from areas positioned around these interest points. Both dense and sparse sampling-based schemes are utilized in this work to generate the data matrix
$$V$$
V
from which non-negative basis elements are estimated.

Section2.Heading: Dictionary initialization
Section2.Para:
Majority of the existing NMF algorithms in the literature follows random non-negative initialization of dictionary matrix
$$W$$
W
. With different random initializations, the
$$\ell ^0$$
ℓ 0
-constrained NMF formulation inevitably converges to distinct local minima. Thus, an appropriate non-random initialization can result faster convergence and minimum approximation error at convergence. The random Acol algorithm [38] is one of the earliest efforts in this area by which each basis element of the visual dictionary is initialized by computing the average of ‘k’ random columns of the data matrix
$$V$$
V
. Though this approach is inexpensive, the final solution is not always unique. Another approach of great importance in dictionary initialization is clustering of the columns of
$$V$$
V
and then initializing
$$W$$
W
by the obtained centroid vectors [39]. This is computationally more complex and K-means clustering itself involves random initialization. As a result it became essential to execute multiple instances of the same dictionary learning algorithm with different random initializations for dictionary
$$W$$
W
to get a better final estimate of the non-negative factors. Hence, a robust initial guess for the dictionary
$$W$$
W
will considerably improve the convergence rate and accuracy of the given approximation problem.

To populate the visual dictionary
$$W$$
W

Thus, the contribution of already selected basis vector is cancelled out from the original collection. This process is repeated until a desired number of basis vectors are obtained. Grabbing the sparsest data vector over each iteration and then subtracting its orthonormal projection onto individual data items helps to identify a set of linearly independent basis vectors from the given observations. Numerical experiments reported in Sect. 7 demonstrated that it serves as a good initial estimate for the actual dictionary that is to be learned.

Section2.Para:
Once an initial estimate of
$$W$$

$$V$$

Section3.Heading: Non-negative sparse encoding of data matrix

Section1.Heading: Visual dictionary-based image representation
Section1.Para: The effectiveness of an image retrieval system ultimately depends on the following factors: the correctness of image representation, the storage requirements of the extracted representation and finally the computational efficiency of the searching scheme. Hence, selecting an appropriate strategy for representing the images and its compactness have great impact on the final retrieval results.

Various techniques have been reported over the past few years to address some of the above-mentioned constraints jointly or in parts. One such approach is to index local image features using vocabulary tree with inverted files [45]. This facilitates the use of larger vocabularies for better retrieval accuracy. However, the accuracy is often limited to a certain extent due to the information loss in feature quantization process and the lack of spatial information of various identified local features. Therefore, after initial matching post-processing techniques for image re-ranking such as Random Sample Consensus (RANSAC) [46] needs to be employed to improve the precision. The re-ranking of image search results again requires random access to raw features of these images. This inevitably increases the memory cost and slow down the search speed. Later on, Spatial pyramid matching [47] and visual phrases [48] tries to encode spatial information of local descriptors into inverted index. Since the encoded spatial information is too weak, the search precision is not as good as that of the RANSAC-based approach.

An alternate direction is the transformation of a set of local descriptors into a compact fixed-size feature vector that can provide comparatively good search accuracy. That is, instead of considering the local descriptors in images separately, they are converted into a global fixed-size representation. This allows us to represent images with a small number of bytes similar to coded global descriptors [49] and at the same time preserves some key properties inherited from local descriptors, such as rotation and scale invariance. The two leading aggregation operation in the literature are Vector of Local Aggregated Descriptors (VLAD) [50] and Fisher vector [51]. In both these approaches, the derivation of an image signature generally involves two steps: encoding and pooling. The encoding process maps each D-dimensional local image descriptor into another form and the pooling step aggregates all encoded features into a single vector. Similar to bag-of-visual-words, initially the local descriptors are mapped to basis vectors of a visual dictionary obtained with vector quantization as in the case of VLAD and Gaussian mixture model for fisher vectors. However, rather than using the occurrence frequency of visual words, these representations calculate statistics of the difference between basis vectors and the local descriptor values. Afterwards, both these methods utilize sum pooling [51] operation to obtain an aggregated image representation. It has been proven in [50] that a compact image representation with as few as 16 bytes is still having retrieval performance closer or higher to that of bag-of-features-based representation. This is the motivation behind the use of aggregated feature vector for image retrieval in the proposed work.

Section2.Heading: Image similarity measure
Section2.Para:
Having extracted the aggregated image signature, the next step is to determine the correspondence between a query and all images present in the database. The proposed system employs Minkowski distance [53] of order one to measure the relevance of a query image in comparison with images already present in the database as depicted by the following equation 27
$$\begin{aligned} D(\mathbb {P}^q,\mathbb {P}^d) = \sum \limits _{i=1}^{K} |p_i^q - p_i^d| \end{aligned}$$

The search process can be accelerated by incorporating certain indexing structures, which in turn has the ability to efficiently organize images present in the given collection. Each dimension of the aggregated image feature corresponds to a basis vector in the learned visual dictionary. This triggers the applicability of inverted file structure [54] to organize images present in various data sets. An inverted file contains a separate entry for each visual term in the learned visual dictionary followed by a list of images IDs in which the particular visual term occurs. To calculate image similarity, a set of candidate images are filtered out from the whole collection by intersecting those rows in the index structure having visual terms with non-zero entries in the given query. The relevance score is then calculated only between these images and the query.

Section1.Heading: Data sets
Section1.Para: Four different data sets with contrasting properties are considered for evaluating the efficiency of the proposed dictionary learning scheme and the resulting image retrieval framework. The details of these four image collections are summarized below.

Scene 15 data set [47]: It contains totally 4,485 images falling into 15 categories. The number of images in each category varies from 210 to 410, with each image is having a fixed size of 300
$$\times $$
×
250 pixels. There is a rich collection of indoor and outdoor scene categories such as: bedroom (216 images), tall building (356 images), coast (360 images), city centre (308 images), forest (328 images), highway (260 images) industrial (311 images), kitchen (210 images), living room (289 images), mountain (374 images), office (215 images), open country (410 images), store (315 images), street (292 images), suburb residences (241 images).

INRIA Holiday data set [55]: It is a collection of 1491 high-resolution personal photos taken from different locations around the globe. This mainly includes a large variety of scene types such as natural, man-made, water, fire effects, etc. Among these, 500 of them are designated as query images. There exists a predefined retrieval list for each one of these queries.

ZuBuD Building data set [56]: The ZuBuD database comprises images of 201 distinct buildings captured randomly from the Zurich city. For each building there are 5 arbitrary view points within the data base. Different viewing conditions involve acquisition angles of the digital camera, changes in illumination conditions and occlusions. This leads to a total of 1,005 images each of size 640
$$\times $$
×
480 pixels. The database is accompanied with an additional query set, consisting of 115 images not originally included in the actual collection. They have been captured with a different camera under different photometric conditions. There is an expected list of returned image associated with each of the 115 query.

Oxford data set [45]: The Oxford building datasets is known for its difficulty to discriminate very similar building facades from each other. These data involve 5,062 images of 11 various Oxford landmarks. A query set containing 5 images from each of the 11 landmarks and their corresponding ground truth retrieval results are also equipped with the original collection. This provides a set of 55 queries over which the proposed image retrieval system can be evaluated.

Section1.Heading: Evaluation of the learned visual dictionary
Section1.Para:
A well-trained visual dictionary is expected to capture the underlying structure present in a given set of input samples. Therefore, this aspect of the learned visual dictionary needs to be analysed thoroughly while judging its competence. For this, two types of experiments are mainly carried out to which the proposed dictionary learning algorithm is applied. One is the approximation of local image regions and the other is the restoration of a given dictionary. The approximation power, adaptation ability and execution time of the proposed method is then calculated and compared with those of the other reported techniques such as NN-KSVD [9], NMF
$$\ell ^0-H$$
ℓ 0
- H
[10] and K-WEB [11]. In all these experiments, algorithms are coded in Matlab and executed within Matlab 7.8 (R2009a) on a PC with a 3.4 GHz Intel Core i7 processor and 8 GB of memory under Windows 7 Operating System.

Section1.Heading: Evaluation of retrieval results
Section1.Para: This section evaluates the retrieval efficiency of the proposed model and provides empirical evidences to demonstrate its superior performance over the traditional approaches. The following subsections describe the quantitative indices used to measure image retrieval accuracy, the selection of appropriate model parameters for the proposed dictionary optimization scheme in connection with effective image retrieval, evaluation of various pooling strategies for building an image representation suitable for retrieval operation and the image search experiments carried out in various data sets.

Section2.Heading: Evaluation metric
Section2.Para:
The relevance of a ranked list of images in response to a given query needs to be analysed to measure the performance of retrieval systems of similar nature. Many standard evaluation techniques have been proposed by researchers over the past few decades. Precision and recall, normally depicted by a precision–recall (PR) curve is the widely used criterion among these. As defined in (30) and (31), precision judge the potential of the system to yield only relevant images while recall indicates the retrieval framework’s ability to return all relevant images. 30
$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Precision}=\frac{\mathrm{Number} \, \mathrm{of} \, \mathrm{relevant} \, \mathrm{images} \, \mathrm{retrieved}}{\mathrm{Total} \, \mathrm{number} \, \mathrm{of} \, \mathrm{images} \, \mathrm{retrieved}} \end{aligned}$$
Precision =

images
retrieved

number
of
images
retrieved
31
$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Recall}=\frac{\mathrm{Number} \, \mathrm{of} \, \mathrm{relevant} \, \mathrm{images} \, \mathrm{retrieved}}{\mathrm{Total} \, \mathrm{number} \, \mathrm{of} \, \mathrm{relevant} \, \mathrm{images} \, \mathrm{in} \, \mathrm{the} \, \mathrm{set}} \end{aligned}$$
Recall =
Number

In the context of a ranked retrieval list, an appropriate set of resultant images are usually formed by selecting the top k returned images. For each such collection, the precision vs recall values can be easily calculated and plotted to get the precision–recall graph (PR curve). Such PR graphs always have a saw-tooth appearance, because if the
$$\textit{(k+1)}$$
( k + 1 )
th image in the obtained list is not a relevant one, then its recall value remains the same as that of the top k images, but precision goes down. On the other hand, precision as well as recall shoots up, if the
$$\textit{(k+1)}$$
( k + 1 )
th image is a relevant one. A standard technique to resolve these irregularities is the interpolated precision: the interpolated precision at the
$$j$$
j
th recall level
$$\textit{r}_j$$
r j
is the largest observed precision for any recall values r between the
$$j$$
j
th and
$$(j+1)$$
( j + 1 )
th level: 32
$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Interpolated \, Precision}\, (r_j)=\max _{r_j \le r \le r_{j+1}} \mathrm{Precision}\,(r) \end{aligned}$$

Instead of directly exploring the entire precision–recall values, it is often better to truncate these figures down to a finite set of values. The 11-point interpolated average precision is the popularly used principle to achieve the desired objective. The interpolated precision values are calculated for each queries at 11 different recall levels of
$$\{0.0,0.1,0.2,\ldots , 0.9,1.0\}$$
{ 0.0 , 0.1 , 0.2 , … , 0.9 , 1.0 }
. At a certain recall level, the average of the interpolated precisions for each image in the query set is measured. Finally, a combined precision–recall graph incorporating all the 11 recall points is plotted to evaluate the overall system performance on a particular query set.

Even though 11-point interpolated PR curve is a suitable candidate to estimate the accuracy of the retrieval system, it often fails to specify whether majority of the relevant images are there at the beginning of the retrieval list. Mean average precision (MAP) is the right alternative to address this issue and can be defined as: 33
$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Mean \, Average \, Precision\,(MAP)}=\frac{1}{Q}\sum _{i=1}^{Q}\mathrm{AP}_i \end{aligned}$$

Average precision (AP) for a given query is the ratio of the sum of the precision values from the rank locations where a relevant image is found in the retrieval list to the total number of relevant images in the database. It is defined as: 34
$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Average \, Precision \,(AP)}=\frac{\sum _{r=1}^{R}P(r)I(r)}{C} \end{aligned}$$

Precision and recall values are inversely connected. An increase in one value is usually at the expense of the other. Therefore, a unified measure which can combine the precision and recall values together to evaluate the the retrieval accuracy is necessary. The F
$$_1$$
1
score serves the purpose well and is defined as the weighted average of the precision and recall values. It is formally defined as: 35
$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{F}_1 \, \mathrm{score} = 2\times \frac{\mathrm{Precision} \times \mathrm{Recall}}{\mathrm{Precision} + \mathrm{Recall}} \end{aligned}$$

Section2.Heading: Selection of pooling strategy
Section2.Para:
Initially, the max pooling and sum pooling strategies for aggregating sparsely encoded local image descriptors are evaluated in the context of image retrieval. In this experiment, mainly two contrasting schemes are adopted to generate the data matrix
$$V$$
V
. Primarily, various key point detectors such as Laplacian-of-Gaussian (LOG) [57] and Harris [58] are applied to locate interest points in images. The local image structure around each observed key point is then described in terms of invariant descriptors such as Scale Invariant Feature Transform (SIFT) [59] or DAISY [60]. Various combinations of these detectors and descriptors create multiple data matrices with diverse characteristics. Second, vectorized gray levels of local image blocks obtained with regular grids are also selected as the column entries of the data matrix
$$V$$
V
. Later on, the proposed dictionary learning algorithm is executed with each of the data matrix generated in the above-mentioned approaches as inputs. In all these experiments dictionary size is fixed at
$$K=175$$
K = 175
and a sparseness value of
$$L=50$$
L = 50
is used. The learned dictionaries are then used to encode various local image features and finally an aggregated feature vector is derived. Table 4 depicts the retrieval results of average and sum pooling-based feature aggregation for various datasets in terms of mean average precision (MAP) values and F
$$_1$$
1
measure. This makes sense that max pooling performs better than the sum pooling when applied to aggregate sparsely encoded local descriptors for image retrieval. Thus, max pooling-based representation is further employed for comparing the performance of the proposed image retrieval system with the state-of-the-art methods.

The notion of co-active dimensions among encoded local descriptors in two images justifies the superior performance of max-pooled aggregated feature vectors for image retrieval. A descriptor
$$\mathbf v $$
v
is said to be active among the
$$T$$
T
local descriptors present in an image, if it possess not less than one basis element
$$i$$
i
such that its sparse code
$$\mathbf h $$
h
fulfil
$$\mathbf h ^{i} = \max \{ \mathbf h _t ^i|t=1,2..T\}$$
h i
= max
{
h t i
| t = 1 , 2 . . T }
. That is, the local descriptor
$$\mathbf v $$
v
has the highest weight for at least one basis vector as compared to the sparse codes of all other local descriptors. Hence, the
$$i$$
i
th component of the aggregated image signature is entirely determined by this active descriptor. Similarly, a set of two local descriptors from different images are said to be co-active, if they have one or more common active dimensions in the corresponding sparse codes. Usually the descriptors from visually similar blocks of two images are closer to each other and are some times more probable to be co-active with identical values in the co-active dimensions of their sparse codes. Relevant images have often large number of visually similar local image features and thus their max-pooled feature vectors will be almost identical as opposed to non-relevant images. Therefore, similarity measured in terms of max-pooled local descriptors often results much better retrieval accuracy.

Section2.Heading: Experimental setup
Section2.Para: The retrieval experiments are conducted using tenfold cross-validation technique. For this to work, images in individual database are arbitrarily divided into ten folds of approximately equal sizes. In each successive experiments, nine image subsets are used for training purpose and the remaining one will act as the query. Thus, each subset is used once as the query. The evaluation metrics presented in subsequent sections refers to the average values computed over these ten trials. The same cross-validation folds are used for all other compared methods.

Section2.Heading:
Fixing the model parameters
$$K$$
K
and
$$L$$
L
Section2.Para:
This section investigates the selection of reasonable values for various parameters of the proposed dictionary learning algorithm in the context of image retrieval. Optimal values for the parameters such as the size of the visual dictionary (
$$K$$
K
) and the sparsity level (
$$L$$
L
) in encoding local descriptors need to be estimated. For this, the average R-Precision values are used. R-Precision for a given query is defined to be the precision after retrieving R images from the collection, where R is the total number of relevant images in the database for the given query. The precision at
$$R$$
R
th position in the ranked retrieval list for a set of query images that has
$$R$$
R
relevant images in the collection is estimated by varying the values of
$$K$$
K
and
$$L$$
L
. Different visual dictionaries can be constructed to sparsely approximate local image descriptors by varying the dictionary size (
$$K$$
K
) and their sparsity level (
$$L$$
L
). Hence, analysing the average R-Precision values obtained in various retrieval experiments serves as the key criterion to fine-tune the values of
$$K$$
K
and
$$L$$
L
. Figure 2 shows the secured average R-Precision values on various data sets when the sparsity level is changed along with the dictionary size. From these results we observe that whatever be the sparsity level, for small dictionary sizes the system fails to yield acceptable precision. As the dictionary size increases and incorporates more hidden structures in its basis elements, then even for small values of sparsity levels it can achieve better precisions. However, it requires more storage and computations for larger dictionaries. Considering all these factors into account, the visual dictionary size and the sparsity level of the codebook optimization framework is fixed at 150 and 40.

Section2.Heading: Retrieval results and discussion
Section2.Para: In this section, the retrieval efficiency of the proposed framework is compared with state-of-the-art systems, including those using bag-of-visual-words (BoVW) and local descriptor aggregation-based image signatures. In this regard, five existing image retrieval systems are selected for the comparison purpose namely Vector of Local Aggregated Descriptor (VLAD) for image retrieval [50], Fisher Vector (FV)-based approach [51], Fuzzy Bag-of-Visual-Words model (Fuzzy-BoVW) [61], weighted bag-of-visual-words model [62] and the direct use of local features for retrieval (SIFT) [63].

Table 5 shows the MAP values and the average F
$$_1$$
1
scores of various aggregation-based image signatures for the retrieval operation. In this experiment, different key point detector and descriptor combinations are employed to characterize local features of images. In the case of all the four data sets and for every possible combination of the key point detectors and descriptors, the proposed sparse encoded feature aggregation technique outperforms the rest of the approaches.

All these experiments successfully demonstrated that encoding and pooling pipeline for local feature aggregation using the proposed
$$\ell _0$$
ℓ 0
-constrained NMF formulation can outperform and replace the state-of-the-art techniques in image retrieval. The proposed codebook optimization scheme is capable of representing rich structures present in images by part-based visual terms. The sparsity of the resulting local descriptor encodings makes it possible to max-aggregate them into a fixed-size feature with admissible loss of information well suited for image retrieval.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: This paper has presented an unsupervised visual dictionary learning scheme which considerably minimizes the approximation error while encoding local image patches. A compressed but precise visual dictionary is learned by combining NMF and sparse coding framework. The expressive power and effectiveness of the generated codebook is tested with two contrasting applications. In both cases, the proposed codebook optimization strategy outperforms existing models. Later on, the learned visual codebook is used to sparsely encode local image descriptors in images. The sparsity of local descriptor encodings in an image allows us to max-aggregate them into a compact yet discriminative feature vector. Experimental results show that the modified representation significantly improves the retrieval performance as compared to the state-of-the-art image retrieval systems. Further scope for future research lies in eliminating noisy visual elements from the dictionary by associating additional constraints with the sparse NMF formulation.
